1. A 4-month-old male infant was brought to the pediatric neurologist due to multiple daily generalized tonic-clonic seizures that began at 2 months of age. His parents report poor feeding, irritability, and developmental regression; he no longer coos or tracks faces as before. On examination, he has hypotonia, poor visual fixation, and episodes of apnea associated with seizures. Electroencephalogram (EEG) reveals a chaotic, hypsarrhythmia-like pattern with multifocal epileptiform discharges. Brain MRI shows nonspecific mild cerebral atrophy without structural malformations. Despite trials of multiple anticonvulsants including phenobarbital and levetiracetam, his seizures remain refractory. Genetic testing identifies a pathogenic mutation in the SLC13A5 gene, consistent with epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, type 6. The care team discusses the prognosis and potential supportive therapies focused on seizure control and developmental support.

ANSWER: He's been having these really strange seizures almost every day, and it's just been so hard to watch. He doesn't seem to want to eat much anymore, and he's been crying a lot and not doing the things he used to do. We’re really worried because he seems different and we don’t know what to do anymore.
